etymologies: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French enbrouder, from en- ‘in, on’ + Old French brouder, broisder ‘decorate with embroidery’, of Germanic origin

definitions: decorate (cloth) by sewing patterns on it with thread

examples.text: she was teaching one of the girls how to embroider
she had already embroidered a dozen little nighties for the babies

shortDefinitions: decorate cloth by sewing patterns on it with thread

definitions: produce (a design) on cloth with thread

examples.text: I embroidered flowers on my jeans

shortDefinitions: sew design on cloth with thread

definitions: add fictitious or exaggerated details to (an account) to make it more interesting

examples.text: she embroidered her stories with colorful detail

shortDefinitions: add fictitious or exaggerated details to account to make it more interesting
